message.content:
{"id": "17993", 
"title": "Bug 17993: Invalid search behavior in Find/Replace feature", 
"description": "When using the Find/Replace feature, the typed entry in the Find or Replace With fields is replaced with a value from the search history. This behavior is similar to autocomplete commonly seen in browsers. However, the desired behavior should allow for a full range of find and replace operations, while respecting the case of the user input. To reproduce, open a document and select Edit > Find/Replace... The issue also affects the Replace With field. ", 
"OB": "The current behavior is to replace the typed entry with a value from the history, which limits the search capabilities and does not respect the case of the user input. This behavior should be changed to allow for a full range of find and replace operations.", 
"EB": "The desired behavior is for the Find/Replace feature to not replace the typed entry with a value from the history. This will allow for a more flexible and accurate search, while respecting the case of the user input.", 
"SR": "To reproduce the issue: 1. Open a document. 2. Select Edit > Find/Replace... 3. In the Find field, type 'a' and click 'Find'. 4. Try to type 'A' in the Find field. The typed entry is replaced with the value from the history, preventing the desired search."}

origin.input_content:
<BUG REPORT>
{'id': '17993', 'title': "Bug 17993Find/Replace shouldn't replace typed entry with value from history", 'description': 'It wouldbe better if what I type isn\'t replaced with a value from the history.The current behaviour seems to be similar to "autocomplete" which isparticularly common in browsers. In the future, perhaps, a full "autocomplete"feature could be provided. ', 'OB': '', 'EB': "Bug 17993Find/Replace shouldn't replace typed entry with value from history For me, it isvery common to perform operations like this.I think the current behaviour to be changed to something more simple whichallows the full range of find and replace operations to be performed. But this should still respect the case of what theuser types. Until then, I think the feature should be removed.To reproduce: Open a document so that EditFind/Replace... becomes available. You shouldn't be able to.The behaviour is similar for the Replace With field. ", 'SR': 'When you type in the "Find" or "Replace With" fields itsearches for entries from a previous search. For example, searching for "hello" and replacing it with "hi" thensearching for "Hello" and replacing it with "Hi" is not possible. Choose EditFind/Replace... Type "a" into the Find field. Click "Find". Try to type "A" into the Find field. '}
